This game wasn't anywhere near what I thought it was going to be. It's literally just W-Key simulator for HOURS, REAL TIME HOURS, to try to get money for more/better trucks.
Zero gameplay of doing multiple pick-ups/drop-offs, loading & unloading, repairing your truck or trailer yourself during trips, and you get 30 seconds of parking for every half hour of driving you do.
All of the cool intriguing aspects of trucking/this game were all automated and untouchable. The only thing you get full control over is w-keying, which you have to do for hours to complete the missions if you want to get paid anything.
Please don't buy this if you are interested in anything other than holding W for hours of your life.

Feeling stressed? 
Thoughts racing through your head? 
Can't focus?
Just need to turn the brain off for a bit?

If you answered "yes" to more than one of these questions, this game might be just for you.
This game is quite relaxing and calming as you barrel down the roads across the Europe, hauling anything from used packaging to heavy machinery (with appropriate DLC) and dry goods between locations.

The gameplay loop is quite satisfying and there is just something strangely "zen" about the landscapes and the vistas around the Europe (somewhat scaled down).

The game was released after American Truck Simulator, but the differences are not major. The main difference in the game is that the scenery is much more detailed and the roads are more narrow and challenging and there is less monotony. In some areas there are a lot of toll booths and security checkpoints which is a little annoying but they become routine eventually.

The game is a little bit DLC-heavy, but aside form map packs and cargo packs that allow more cargo types, they are not really required. The map DLCs cover most of the EU, with plans to cover the entire EU. I believe so there will be plenty more to explore in the future.

Would I recommend buying this full price? Maybe.
On a sale? Definitely, with a few map expansions.

The game is well made and has realistic driving and traffic. Joining the World of Trucks account lets you deliver cargo for it and engage in events. Sometimes getting money is hard but you you can get a quick loan from the bank, you will have to pay this off eventually. 

Nothing is rushed and the map is very large. You can partake in free roam with no trailer or cargo and go where ever you want. Following road rules results in less fines and less penalties. You can purchase your own trucks and trailers and hire people to drive them. These trucks and trailers are fully customisation at service stations located all across the map. 

Good game, would recommend you give this game a try.

The game is surprisingly realistic and immersive, with detailed graphics, physics, and sound effects. The roads and landscapes are based on real locations, and the traffic and weather are dynamic and unpredictable. You have to follow the rules of the road, such as speed limits, traffic lights, and tolls, and you have to manage your fuel, fatigue, and damage. You also have to deal with the challenges of parking, loading, and unloading your trailer.

You can choose from different types of jobs, such as quick jobs, freight market, or external contracts, and earn money and experience. You can use your money to buy new trucks, upgrade them, or customize them with paint jobs, accessories, and decals. You can also buy garages, hire drivers, and assign them to trucks and jobs. You can improve your skills and reputation by completing different types of deliveries, such as urgent, long distance, fragile, or eco-friendly, and unlock new perks and rewards.

The game is also very mod-friendly, with a lot of community-made content available to download and enhance your experience. You can find mods that add new trucks, trailers, maps, traffic, weather, sounds, and more. You can also join online multiplayer servers and interact with other players.

Euro Truck Simulator 2 is a game that will appeal to anyone who enjoys driving, simulation, or management games. It is easy to pick up, but hard to master, and it offers a lot of replay value and fun. It will make you feel like a real truck driver, and it will make you appreciate the beauty and diversity of Europe.

[h2] Not for everyone [/h2]

This is [u] not the game for everyone [/u] it it for those who like something that is monotonic. I find this game meditative. I am not looking for the simulation reality. I have limited knowledge for autos in general, so it is out of my bounds of comprehension. What I can say that it has a decent graphics, great ideas for a gameplay, great settings for a little bit ease down the gameplay for some guys like me, who do not care much of the simulation reality, and (as I get it) for someone who whants more simulation like manually using the transmission system.

[h2] The labor of love so to say [/h2]

You can add about 300+ hours to my score in this account since I remember playing on my dad's PC in my school years. It is astonishing that after quite many years (regarding the game dev industry) updates are still going and not just small updates for bug fixing but the whole new things in the game.

Euro Truck Simulator 2,is honestly,one of the best games in the simulator genre on Steam currently avabile. It's Developer,SCS Software. They are truly the most caring and dedicated developing group ive ever seen. Even being such a small developer compared to others. They still managed to hit the tops and make it up on the list of the best reviewed games on steam. Now how did they do that? First,they pay so much attention to places they dont even list on the map. It's insane. The ammount of accuracy,and situations is so good for a game. I bought Road to the black sea dlc last week,and it's the most realistic dlc out of all since i live in Romania. They literally got everything right from the roads to the houses and enviroment. Even the plants are accurate to real life. its honestly insane. And SCS Software keeps up with the comunity with updates and sneak peeks constantly. SCS Software has honestly never dissapointed me. Best game for 5 Euros on sale. I reccomend it.

Having way too much fun! Wanted to give the game a try as I've been driving tractors with trailers in real life in my teenage years, and wanted to see if that would be an advantage in game, and it most definitely is. I'm already 7 hours in with the game, after not even a full day since I first made my character.

Whilst ETS2 is rightly billed as a simulator, there are a couple other intriguing layers beneath the driving elements.  This is a very legit open-world game, for one, spanning much of Europe, especially if you've collected all the DLC.  ETS2 also offers the chance to become a trucking tycoon of sorts - with the ability to bring on new garages, employees, trucks, trailers, and more.  

The game's economic layer, with banking and loans to repay, adds an enjoyable challenge and lends depth that a pure-play driving simulator would struggle to attain.  Repairing, restoring, customizing, and upgrading your trucks is also a real treat, with physical effects on driving (e.g.  maximum freight/cargo weight, acceleration, hill traversal, maneuverability, etc.) that often make the expense quite worthwhile.

Driving itself is a heady mix of beauty (the HD skyboxes are often gorgeous), challenge, relaxation, and time management.  There's plenty of variety in the job market, which only expands further as you open up new skills, locations, and even your own trailers.

Capsule review: addictive, beautiful, relaxing (although it can be tense at times), challenging, and rewarding.   Highly recommended.

P.S.  Expect to spend a while setting up and perfecting your control scheme and button mapping.  There are plenty of guides, though, to draw from.
I would play this game daily if I had the time. It is enjoyable with and without friends. Talking from experience. And after you play for a while you won't resit buying the DLC's.

When I brought the game with Balkans Bundle, along with DLCs, my account did not get deleted from the demo version of Euro Truck Simulator 2. I just brought my MAN TGX 18.360 after that. This game is downright awesome! It's a must-have for all truck enthusiasts but also for people who enjoy just casually cruising on the roads. The base game itself is worth it, but for the full experience, I recommend buying at least one of the DLC bundles (they're always 15% off). I recommend playing with either a steering wheel, or if you don't have one, a controller. Even with a very low-spec PC you'll be able to run the game smoothly and the graphics won't be that bad.

Some of the more important in-game aspects that need to be considered though are:
1. The traffic AI can get messed up sometimes and it can be a real pain to navigate the roads.
2. This only happened to me once, but the highway was blocked because of a huge accident and I got rerouted, but since there weren't any roads nearby, the GPS kept sending me in circles.
3. As I mentioned before, the base-game is really just Germany, Switzerland, northern Italy, northern France, and UK.
4. As mentioned before, mouse and keyboard are okay, but they're definitely not the best. A controller is the minimum to a smooth, non-problematic, and easy gameplay.

Altogether, I highly recommend the game, even with its little flaws. If you're looking for a relatively affordable, fun, easy to learn game (which involves driving around), then Euro Truck Simulator 2 is perfect for you.

Perhaps this game can get boring at a long term because it has no variation other than the places you go through, but it always has the capacity of entertaining me a few hours those boring days in which you don't have anything else to do.
It is visually very good though you can improve the graphics with mods, and the AI is sometimes annoying but acceptable over all.
I highly recommend the use of mods, the purchase of certain DLC's (in sale if possible) and playing online to improve your experience exponentially. 
I would also highly recommend the use of a steering wheel instead of playing with the keyboard or a controller if you really want to feel like driving a truck. With a steering wheel you will achieve a more realistic and enjoyable experience.

Euro Truck Simulator 2 is like no other game where you spend time with it, level up, get better than others, and boast your progress. I mean, of course, you could do that if you wanted to, but I believe that many people play this game just because of how it makes them feel.
Free. Open. Liberated.
A game worth cherishing if you've got no competition in mind and just want to spend your time peacefully carrying trailers from one city to another, passing through countless forests and iconic landmarks that some major cities offer (some through DLC packs). Unlike games like Grand Theft Auto, for example, which would let you rush through the map with fast, exquisite vehicles, this focuses more on the follow-the-rules mechanism where you would drive your truck how you would in real life, following traffic laws and catching up with delivery deadlines. You keep track of your sleep and fuel that you can replenish at any one of the numerous gas stations that you can find across the map. Gives you a sense of realism and the slow-paced atmosphere of the game helps you soothe your mind and give it some time to relax.

It has decent graphics that don't turn your PC into an oven but still help you cherish the realism using good shadow and lightning effects. You can install mods from the amazing creations posted by community members on the Steam Workshop to customize your truck and trailer even further, making them look like your own. 

The only complaint I have with the game is that sometimes the freeways are very monotonous, with the shrubbery and the trees around you looking almost identical almost everywhere. Sure, there are mountainous regions and other different environments to drive in but most of the freeways are the same with very minimal change in the setting. A little more variety would've made me and others who think so, satisfied. 

Overall an amazing game with a lot of support from the devs and somewhat frequent updates with fixes and new content. The DLCs are worth getting and quite reasonably priced for what they offer.

If I see any other simulator games like this in the future, they'll always remind me of ETS2. :D

This game brings nostalgia back to me, i remember the first driving games that i have ever played was 18 Wheels of Steel, i was 5 years old back then still learning how to read and count but also bad at the game at the time my father also teach me how to play the game, but right now i'm 24 and i can play the game without anyone helping me or teaching me while my father just watch me play the game besides, the time has changed but the joy is not, i'm proud that my dad introduces me to truck driving games.

Now for this game i have a lot of things to say, i like trucks since i was in kindergarten so i'm kinda bias to reviewing this game, the models and graphic of the trucks is so detailed not just the outside but even on the inside, i like the driving physics as well because it gives me the sense of driving a real semi-truck (i never drive one in real life), i like how the cab lean and how the wheels bounce according to the surfaces of the road, i also like the raining physics it makes me feel like i'm driving in real-life too. The customization is very good, there's so many things to change to fit our taste and needs, not just the semi-truck itself but the trailer is also customizable. The settings of the game is pretty vast, not just the controls, audio, video settings but you can also fiddle with the gameplay settings like traffic density, weather variable, how fast the time of the day goes by, and bunch of other things to change to fit into your playstyle. I also appreciate the effort that they put to this game, like the cities and countries from Europe is as detailed as they are in real-life, the roads and the traffic lights and the building and the bridges.

In conclusion this game is worth it for you and those who likes stuff about trucks and all, this game i obviously is not an off-road truck driving but it's about logistic truck driving, you deliver stuff to the destination on time or even before the predicted expected time, you can play this game and relax you don't need to rush everything, just choose the mission with the time range that suits your capability, that way you can relax and really enjoy the game as you drive and progress trough it.

I have a dream, that one day there will be a full fledged trucking simulator, with a map that allows you to visit virtually every country in the world, along with a MMO model, where both players and AI travel these virtual roads together, the ultimate trucking simulator.

Sadly there's no such game like what I described.

That said, this lovely game, along with a good pack of mods, is the closest you're gonna get to the ultimate trucking experience, there's simply no other competitor, none.

What can I say about SCS truck simulator in 2022? Everybody knows it.

Everybody knows it is as big as a world, it's made with fantastic attention to detail and with the latest lighting engine it looks better than anything demanding barely half of your PC's hardware power even if you forget to upgrade it for the last 10 years. It has a lot of trucks, trailers and loads for them so you will never be bored.

What else?

Everybody knows it has bugged speed limit that is prone to jump up and down without any proper signage causing police to charge you while you are not guilty. You will also be charged for every crash the AI car makes and who cares it's not your fault as you are probably guilty for driving in this game at the first place. 

The local AI is a legend in itself still doing strange things despite being 10 years in development and keeping the well-earned title 'Artificial Idiot'. It knows nothing about traffic rules, it yields when it should go and attacks you when it should stand still. It drives on red and stays on green, it can completely block the traffic on a 6-lane highway just to let a single car to pull out of a gas station. It is written by people who don't drive and the reason why almost nobody complains is the majority of players doesn't have a real life driving experience too.

Trucks galore is an illusion as at least half of them are unusable because of awful sound. I'm not talking aestetics, the engine noise contains very loud and unpleasant low frequency leftovers just physically unbearable to listen. How could anyone be so unprofessional? What went wrong? Deaf sound engineer? Maybe. Cheap headphones? Who knows. It is made as it was made by some chap within the small SCS team and nobody will return to revise it. 

SCS is a group of amateurs happened to be in their own niche making their niche product as good as they can. The game has more problems than many other titles and would probably fail if only there was at least one more contender... But there are none.

So.

Verdict: Euro truck simulator 2 is the best truck simulator at the moment. Number one out of... one.

P.S. There're no truck enthusiasts in SCS so if you are this type of person be prepared for the worse: incorrect badging, fictional options, missing parts and of course made-up chassis with unrealistic wheelbases. Trucks are just toys here.

Euro Truck Simulator 2 is a captivating and meticulously detailed simulation that delivers a unique and surprisingly relaxing experience. The game invites players into the driver's seat of a truck, allowing them to embark on long journeys across Europe's roads while delivering cargo.

What sets Euro Truck Simulator 2 apart is its attention to realism and the depth of its gameplay. The meticulously recreated landscapes, detailed truck models, and the sensation of driving on varied terrains create an immersive and authentic experience. The game's progression system, where players build their trucking empire by completing deliveries, acquiring new vehicles, and hiring drivers, adds a sense of accomplishment and growth.

ETS2's open-world nature allows for freedom in exploration and route planning. The diverse selection of cargo and the ability to customize trucks to suit individual preferences offer a sense of personalization. Additionally, the game's community-driven mods and regular updates contribute to its longevity, ensuring a wealth of content and features to keep players engaged.

For players seeking a relaxing yet engaging simulation experience, Euro Truck Simulator 2 delivers an enjoyable and rewarding journey through Europe's roads, capturing the essence of the trucking industry with meticulous detail.

[h1] PROS: [/h1]
Endless truck customization, especially if you use mods
Works with most steering wheels, super fun with force feedback
Stream real life radio stations in game
Great GPS navigation including voice
Lots of little things like ability to adjust mirrors and roll down windows
You can choose how realistic you want it to be, many settings can be changed.

[h1] CONS: [/h1]
The way tickets are given by police isn't very realistic (they just instantly take your money, you don't get "pulled over" or anything like that.
DLC areas have some significant framerate drops especially around the towns
AI traffic is a little too friendly and isn't all that realistic but there are mods to fix that
The modding rabbit hole goes deep. I play with like 27 mods active including things like weather and sound effect changes, interior decorations and many more which can lead to issues, but is hard to resist.

Overall I HIGHLY recommend this game. If you are debating buying this game I would say just go for it, I very much doubt it will disappoint you.

Before I played it, I never understood the appeal of this game. Now I play both this and ATS. Why? 

1. While I'm fascinated with open world games, I haven't ever played a game of this scale. Let's take GTA V for example. The open world in that game is huge but only focused on one city. You might argue it's comparing apples to oranges, and that would be apt because the designers of that game have focused a lot more on details than say, ETS2 or ATS, for example. Fair point. But sometimes I want to travel large distances and see many different architectures, sights and significant changes in scenery over several days or nights without loading screens in between; kind of like a road trip. You can't do that in GTA V because it's confined to one city and you can go from coast to coast in a sportscar in under 4 minutes flat. Not the same kinda vibe. ATS and especially, ETS2 takes it to a new level. You just seamlessly transition from one country to another and witness the change in your surroundings in real time.

2. I'm a quiet, introverted person who likes to play games by myself but I'm unfortunately surrounded by extroverts who love talking my ear off, either on the phone or at work. I can't afford to play games that require significant attention investment when they're telling me their mundane bullshit; truck sims are great for playing while "listening" to them (or anything really, like even a podcast) because they don't require your full attention and intensive hand-eye coordination. You can also play them when you just want to smoke weed, eat pizza and chill with some relaxing music playing in the background.

But now it's got to a point where I find myself desperately trying to find something to listen to because the itch to play the game is there even when I don't have something else to do alongside.

Oh and just a heads up- I found ETS2's economy much harder than ATS':

- Garages cost more in ETS2 than in ATS

- Trucks cost more in ETS2 than in ATS

- Payouts are shittier with all DLCs in ETS2 than in ATS without any DLCs (with the all skills maxed out in both games)

- Vehicle insurances are a thing in ATS and for a small one time fee, you're covered for all damage for life whereas in ETS2, you break the bank everytime some dumbass scratches your truck

- Employees are more likely to turn up empty handed in ETS2 than in ATS

- Employees have negligible to negative income in ETS2 than in ATS

Imagine waking up long before the sun rises in the morning and getting into your car for an hour long commute into the city, where you work at least eight hours for a paycheck with ever-dwindling purchasing power, before you spend another hour in the car going home. Now imagine coming home and playing a video game that isn't a second, unpaid job that requires hours of driving. Believe it or not, there are people that do this, and they tell themselves that their lives are fulfilling. The rest of us know that work makes you free, and we buy DLC so that we can do imaginary work for even longer periods of time. Then, when we're too tired for that, we lay in our beds so that we can have stress dreams about paperwork we can't figure out how to fill out before the alarm buzzes and we get to do it all over again. One day, Death will wrap his icy grip around my broken body and whisk me off to a place where, God willing, I can toil for eternity in an indestructible vessel designed for nothing but the hardest of labor. Until then, there's my truck.

Euro Truck Simulator is a game that might not sound too exciting on the surface, after all, it's all about driving a truck. And well, that's pretty much it.

The main premise is simple: drive trucks. However, within this seemingly straightforward concept lies a world of enjoyment. The game offers a wide variety of trucks to choose from, and the thrill of unlocking numerous upgrades at different levels keeps you engaged and eager to progress.

One of the standout features is the sheer number of deliveries available, spanning various distances and locations. The sense of satisfaction from successfully completing these deliveries is oddly rewarding.

One minor downside, though, is that the map can feel a bit limited without all the available DLCs. However, even without the additional content, the game manages to offer an enjoyable experience.

What sets Euro Truck Simulator apart is its relaxing nature. It's not an action-packed behemoth; rather, it's a game that lets you unwind and enjoy the simplicity of driving through scenic routes.

Admittedly, it might not be everyone's cup of tea, but for those seeking a more laid-back gaming experience, Euro Truck Simulator hits the mark. I liked it.

I've been playing this game for a while now and I think I can give it a review other than good, or not good.

In my subjective opinion the game is great, it allows me to relax, get away from everyday worries, recharge my batteries, and after all, that's what it's all about.

Euro Truck Simulator 2 is constantly updated and, what is not common in games, it gets better every time. The developers really listen to the community, the interaction between the players and the developers is amazing. The community events, for which you can get items for your steam inventory, are interesting. Some of the community events are mirrored in events that happened in real life. As for the items you can get, they are truck/trailer paintings, interior decoration items, or the main menu background.

The physics of the trucks are not simulation, which may bother some, but for the most part I think it is enjoyable. The vehicles are easy to drive on the keyboard (especially with mouse steering), the game pad, but the most fun is with the steering wheel. The game allows you to choose the type of parking, for those who don't want to stress unnecessarily, you can choose to park easily or even skip it altogether. Of course, the truck needs to be refuelled and it is worth remembering that the vehicle and parts wear out from driving, or get damaged from accidents. Unfortunately, this damage is not visual.

The game has a company economy, where vehicles can be purchased, modified and employees can be hired to use the trucks purchased. The economy is not complicated or challenging, which can be a plus for beginners. The option to buy garages in European cities makes it easier to expand the company and provides space for the truck collection.

A game definitely worth buying, even more so because of the quality and quantity of content compared to the price. The DLCs extending the possibilities to explore the map of Europe are well worth the price, they add hours of additional entertainment and, despite the scaling of the map, are rich in detail, familiar buildings and monuments and, above all, made with commitment and love. Additions like the Italia DLC or the newly added Balkan areas are downright beautiful.

It is worth adding that the game has an official multiplayer mode, but there is also a huge TruckersMP mod that is supported by the game's developers.

TLDR it's worth buying, the game is often on promotion and provides many hours of gaming and relaxation.

Considering most simulators are low budget and badly made, this one is really good quality, very easily modded, entirely customizable, etc. Players can drive through stunning landscapes in a variety of properly modeled trucks, giving an authentic and enjoyable experience to anyone who plays it. This game is a 8/10 for me. It's really a great game but it does not deserve to be called perfect.

I'll start with the cons to show its flaws first:
-It doesn't feel like a full simulator but more like an arcade. Buying the game for pure realism is a false hope. For example its missing features like dirt, scratches or different factors that should be done by nature. The resting periods aren't realistic and the money system feels to easy. You get way to much money, while in real life you earn €0.75 to €1.25 per km you'll get already €5-10 per km in the starting phase of your career. 
-It's missing some features like a full blockade of the highway and realistic traffic jams .
-The rain is very unrealistic. Taking pictures or just drivng around during rain looks bad as the rain looks more like little lazers than actual rain drops.
-There are to many dlcs. Starting with the many, many paint jobs which mostly aren't necesary as you get better options through mods. Then you have to many brand dlc without enough content. You can buy alot of truck and trailer addons but they lack of content. When installing 1 or 2 mods (SISL interior/Signs for trucks) you'll get more addons for the trucks than when buying the dlcs.
-They make to many different map addons. For example, there shouldn't be a greek dlc after selling the west balkans for 20€. And while working on the greek dlc, they are also putting work into supposable 11 more map dlcs(https://youtu.be/1og9xeh3n50?si=wkbIWOu2qBy_qZa6). I think its great that they're trying to expand the map but they should focus on rebuilding the older parts on the map and max. one new project at a time, as for example the west balkans feel badly optimized especially for low/mid-range pcs.
-The ingame performance is really bad. On some points of the map you'll get easily max fps (v-sync turned on) while on others you'll have ~20 and lags with the same graphic settings.
-The convoy mode is really bad. While it's hard to get it working in the first place, it it harder to join one as it has problems like, not showing the convoy of other people, being very laggy and having low fps. Also the AI has troubles with the convoy mode as they are driving on different rules (feels like driving in a polish city) in there.
-Another problem with AI is that they often forget you exist this problems often occurs with highway entrys as they seem to have not listened during driving school and just drive onto the highway at the end of the interweaving lane and just drive into your side. Also sometimes the AI just crashes into eachother and isn't able to sort it out getting stuck in the middle of the road, blocking the traffic leading to more AI crashes.
-Some added features feel badly done, e.g. the used truck dealer is to expensiv making it a bad alternative to the regular dealer. Also the new repair system is very unclear especially for new players and looks bad.
-The map editor is way to hard to obtain and is hard to understand and needs alot of knowledge before being usable.

These are in my opionion the biggest problems with the game. Some of them fall away if you e.g. dont want pure realism and just like to drive around.

My pros for the game would be that:
-You can always play the game, whenever you're bored you can just switch to ets2 and build new trucks, explore the roads, or have fun with mods.
-It's very easy to understand for new players, playing the game for 20-30 minutes is enough to understand the basics.
-The driving is done well, don't have a wheel? Just use a controller. DOn't have a controller or any battery? Just use your keyboard and mouse, it might feels weird in the  beginning but for simple driving its enough.
-The game can be modified really easy. You can download many good mods in the workshop but also using third party websites for mods is no problem.
-The fanbase is very friendly, unlike in other games the players are nice and open to help and play with you.
-The graphics can be astonishing just mind you that you'll need a highend pc for that. 
-The graphics are easy to adjust for low end pcs so you can get okayish graphics with a potato.
-SCS focuses on their games and keeps them as they are instead of releasing new games every year with barely any new content.
-SCS does listen to their fanbase and work more on stuff that their current players want instead of generating simple money.

Even tho I named a lot of cons, you musn't forget that they are my cons and you could have different views of whats important. If you want simple driving and something to do when bored you should buy it. If you're looking for pure realism it can be a options but you should look at different games like Alaskan road trucker or snow runner. Also you should expect that it can get expensive over time if you're buying a dlc sometimes. I personally love the game and couldn't live without it.

Euro Truck Simulator is a surprisingly meditative journey through the highways of Europe, where the thrill of hauling cargo competes with the serenity of the open road. The attention to detail in recreating real-life landscapes and truck models is commendable, offering a visually immersive experience. The game's slow-paced realism may not be everyone's cup of tea, but for those seeking a unique blend of simulation and relaxation, it's a winner. Just be prepared for the occasional traffic jam and the inexplicable joy of discovering a virtual rest stop. Buckle up, enjoy the scenery, and embrace the zen of trucking.

Overall great game that i can't fully enjoy just because my eyes hurt from this game's lack of proper anti-aliasing.

Edit: Found a fix in the form of a mod posted in SCS Software forum. it is Temporal Anti Aliasing/DLSS/DLAA by snowymoon. There's also another fix by using Nvidia Profile Inspector posted in Roextended forum but for some reason it won't work for any resolution between (but not including) 720p and 1080p.

While those fixes help fixing the anti aliasing issue, i'd rather have a graphics option that is properly tested and implemented in the game by the devs rather than an external workaround that will probably stop working the second a new game update comes out.

Besides that, the game is amazing and is one of the best games in the simulator genre. It's continuously getting updated and have good quality DLCs but besides that it also have plenty of mods to customize the game. Highly recommend trying it out but i advise you to use the anti aliasing fix because otherwise the jagged edges will ruin your experience.

Euro Truck Simulator 2 is a game that immerses you in the world of trucks and roads. You can choose one of seven licensed truck brands and customize it to your liking by adding various details such as lights, bars, horns, beacons, exhaust pipes, and much more. You can travel across more than 60 European countries, visiting real cities, roads, and landmarks. You can transport a variety of goods, from food to chemicals, from building materials to cars. You can develop your own transportation company by buying garages, hiring drivers, managing your fleet, and maximizing profits.

The game has very high quality graphics and sound that create an atmosphere of realism and immersion. You can feel how your truck reacts to different road conditions, weather, traffic and other factors. You can customize the difficulty level of the game by selecting different parameters such as speed, fuel, damage, police, fines, and others. You can also choose different game modes such as career, free play, multiplayer and others.

The game has a great community support that creates different modifications for the game by adding new trucks, maps, roads, cities, landscapes, music, sounds and much more.

Graphics: ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐

Euro Truck Simulator 2 (ETS2) boasts stunning graphics that immerse players in a realistic and visually captivating trucking experience. The attention to detail in the landscapes, cities, and the trucks themselves is exceptional. The dynamic weather system adds an extra layer of realism, with raindrops trickling down the windshield and the sun casting long shadows across the highways. From bustling cityscapes to serene countryside, the graphics in ETS2 contribute significantly to the overall enjoyment of the game.

Truck Variety: ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐

One of ETS2's standout features is its extensive collection of meticulously modeled trucks from various manufacturers. Whether you're a fan of Volvo, Scania, Mercedes-Benz, or others, the game offers a diverse selection of vehicles, each with its own unique characteristics. The attention to detail extends beyond the exterior, encompassing the interior cabins and controls, providing an authentic feel for players who appreciate the nuances of different truck models.

Realistic Driving Physics: ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐

ETS2 excels in delivering a realistic driving experience. The physics engine accurately simulates the weight and handling of the trucks, requiring players to navigate turns, slopes, and varied road conditions with precision. The inclusion of features like trailer sway and realistic braking further enhances the immersion, making each journey feel like a genuine trucking adventure.

Open World Exploration: ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐

The open-world design of ETS2 is expansive and richly detailed, offering a vast European landscape for players to explore. From major cities to scenic countryside, the game captures the essence of trucking across diverse terrains. The freedom to choose routes, explore hidden gems, and take on different jobs adds depth to the gameplay, providing a sense of freedom and discovery.

Career Progression: ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐

ETS2's career progression system is both engaging and rewarding. As players complete deliveries, they earn experience points and money, allowing them to unlock new trucks, upgrades, and access to more challenging and lucrative jobs. The sense of achievement and progression keeps players invested in the long haul, making every delivery feel like a step forward in their virtual trucking career.

Multiplayer Experience (Truckers MP): ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐

For those seeking a social dimension, Euro Truck Simulator 2 supports multiplayer through a third-party program called Truckers MP. This feature enables players to convoy with friends, interact with others in the virtual trucking community, and engage in collaborative journeys. Coordinating deliveries, forming virtual trucking companies, and sharing the road with fellow players enhance the overall experience, turning a solo adventure into a dynamic and enjoyable journey.

In conclusion, Euro Truck Simulator 2 is a masterclass in the simulation genre, offering a meticulously crafted world, realistic driving mechanics, and a wealth of content to keep players engaged. Whether you're a trucking enthusiast or a gamer seeking a unique and immersive experience, ETS2, along with Truckers MP, delivers on all fronts, earning its place as a must-play title.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

How to cook the most delicious pancakes with milk:

1. Break eggs into a bowl, add salt and sugar. Mix with a whisk or fork until smooth (no whisking required).

2. Pour about 200 ml of milk into the eggs and stir.

3. Add flour and stir until smooth (the consistency of the dough is like thick sour cream).

4. Pour in the remaining milk (about 300 ml), stir. The dough should be liquid and easy to pour.

5. Pour in vegetable oil. Mix the dough and let stand for 15-20 minutes.

6. Heat a pan for pancakes (preferably cast iron) and grease it with a thin layer of vegetable oil.

7. Pour half a scoop or scoop of dough into the center of the frying pan (depending on the diameter of the frying pan) and quickly spread it over the entire surface in a thin layer, turning the pan slightly.

8. When the edges of the dough begin to dry out and slightly brown, lift the pancake with a thin wide spatula and carefully turn it over. Let the pancake brown a little on the other side.

9. Using a spatula, remove the finished pancakes from the pan, transfer to a plate and generously grease with melted butter.

Euro Truck Simulator 2 is nothing short of a masterpiece in the world of simulation gaming. From the moment I first revved up my virtual engine and hit the open road, I was hooked on the unparalleled experience that this game offers. As a seasoned gamer, I can confidently say that Euro Truck Simulator 2 is more than just a game; it's a captivating journey that immerses players in the mesmerizing world of trucking across Europe.

One of the most remarkable aspects of Euro Truck Simulator 2 is its stunning attention to detail. The meticulously crafted landscapes, diverse cities, and realistic road networks create an environment that feels alive and dynamic. Whether you're cruising through the bustling streets of Paris, navigating the intricate highway systems of Germany, or enjoying the scenic beauty of the Italian countryside, every inch of the in-game world reflects a level of craftsmanship that is truly commendable.

The vast array of trucks available in the game is another highlight. From the iconic Mercedes-Benz and Volvo to the powerful Scania and MAN, each truck is faithfully recreated with an astonishing level of accuracy. The customization options allow players to personalize their trucks to suit their preferences, adding a layer of personalization that enhances the overall gaming experience. The sense of pride and attachment that comes with driving your customized rig across Europe is truly unparalleled.Euro Truck Simulator 2 is nothing short of a masterpiece in the world of simulation gaming. I saw Ryan Gosling at a grocery store in Los Angeles yesterday. I told him how cool it was to meet him in person, but I didn’t want to be a douche and bother him and ask him for photos or anything.

He said, “Oh, like you’re doing now?”

I was taken aback, and all I could say was “Huh?” but he kept cutting me off and going “huh? huh? huh?” and closing his hand shut in front of my face. I walked away and continued with my shopping, and I heard him chuckle as I walked off. When I came to pay for my stuff up front I saw him trying to walk out the doors with like fifteen Milky Ways in his hands without paying.

The girl at the counter was very nice about it and professional, and was like “Sir, you need to pay for those first.” At first he kept pretending to be tired and not hear her, but eventually turned back around and brought them to the counter.

When she took one of the bars and started scanning it multiple times, he stopped her and told her to scan them each individually “to prevent any electrical infetterence,” and then turned around and winked at me. I don’t even think that’s a word. After she scanned each bar and put them in a bag and started to say the price, he kept interrupting her by yawning really loudly.
